title: AB 1685
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code establishes civil penalties for violations of emission control laws, with a maximum penalty of $37,500 per violation. Violations related to portable fuel containers or small off-road engines may incur a penalty of up to $500 per unit. Manufacturers or distributors may be required to pay the penalty and ensure compliance with emission control laws to continue selling regulated products in the state. The state board adjusts maximum penalties for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Penalties collected are deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43151 prohibits the sale, import, or use of uncertified motor vehicles or engines in California. The article does not apply to vehicles acquired for replacing a damaged or stolen vehicle, vehicles transferred by inheritance or court decree, or vehicles sold after a specific legislative amendment date if registered before that date. This chapter does not apply to motor vehicles with a certificate of conformity under the federal Clean Air Act, originally registered in another state by a resident who moves to this state and provides evidence of previous registration. This provision takes effect 180 days after regulations are adopted for certifying new direct import vehicles. Section 43154 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose civil penalties for violations of emission control laws. The penalty can be up to $37,500 for manufacturers or distributors and up to $10,000 for dealers. Compliance with emission control laws may be required for continued sale of motor vehicles in the state. A dealer violating emission control laws may face a civil penalty of up to $10,000 as per Section 43154 of the Health and Safety Code. The penalty amount can be adjusted for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index by the state board. Any action to recover a penalty under this section shall be brought in the name of the people of the State of California in the superior court of the county where the violation occurred, by the Attorney General on behalf of the state board, or by the district attorney, county attorney, or city attorney. Penalties adjudged by the court shall be deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43211 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. Section 43211 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to require new motor vehicles in California to meet emission standards set by the state board. Manufacturers selling vehicles that fail to meet these standards may face civil penalties up to $37,500 per vehicle. Additionally, penalties for not meeting zero-emission vehicle credit requirements are capped at $5,000 per credit. Penalties collected will be deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund. The civil penalty for failure to meet zero-emission vehicle credit requirements is capped at $5,000 per credit. The state board will adjust the maximum penalty for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index. Any penalty collected will be deposited into the General Fund. Any penalty recovered under this section will go into the General Fund. Manufacturers or distributors failing to meet emission standards may face a civil penalty of up to $37,500 per non-compliant vehicle sold in the state. The executive officer of the state board may require payment of penalties and compliance with emission control laws as conditions for further vehicle sales in the state. The state board can adjust penalties for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Penalties recovered will be deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund. The board may order vehicle manufacturers to comply with emissions standards for certified vehicles, with compliance required for continued sales in the state.
